docs.snippet: If Obama wins, what do Republicans have to fear?...
docs.lead_paragraph: If Barack Obama wins the presidency tonight, as seems very likely, what should conservatives fear most about his administration? Reason's Nick Gillespie, no liberal Democrat, is having a hard time finding much to worry about. Gillespie writes at Hit and Run, Reason's staff blog:

docs.snippet: Six thousand miles away from the White House on the streets of Baghdad, the American election is overwhelmingly seen through the prism of one, single and immediate issue far closer to home. Whether President Bush's successor should remove the Amer...
docs.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD -- Six thousand miles away from the White House on the streets of Baghdad, the American election is overwhelmingly seen through the prism of one, single and immediate issue far closer to home. Whether President Bush's successor should remove the American troops and when.

headline.main: Analysis from the Street: Black and Blue State

byline.original: By STEPHEN FARRELL AND MUDHAFER AL-HUSAINI

docs.snippet: On Election Day 2008 voters finally get their say after a long and compelling campaign for the presidency....
docs.lead_paragraph: We can hardly believe the day has arrived (will somebody pinch us?) when one of the longest, most compelling chapters in our nation's political history draws to a close. On Tuesday an election that has often taken on outsized proportions comes down to individual voters across the country who, in big cities and small towns, will select the 44th President of the United States. Today is their day.
docs.abstract: On Election Day 2008 voters finally get their say after a long and compelling campaign for the presidency.

headline.main: The Early Word: The Voters Decide

docs.snippet: 2008 was the year that YouTube became a mainstream tool for political communication.      Most-Watched Obama Video: Senator Barack Obama's sweeping exploration of race in America, delivered in March, in the midst of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr....
docs.lead_paragraph: 2008 was the year that YouTube became a mainstream tool for political communication. Most-Watched Obama Video: Senator Barack Obama's sweeping exploration of race in America, delivered in March, in the midst of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. controversy. More than 5.1 million views, despite its length -- 37 minutes, 39 seconds -- marking YouTube's emergence as a vehicle for substantive discourse, not just silly clips.
